summary: By FAR the most upsetting/unnerving thing in any marvel movie is in Ant Man when Scott hits a Thomas the tank engine toy with a...
body:
By FAR the most upsetting/unnerving thing in any marvel movie is in Ant Man when Scott hits a Thomas the tank engine toy with a growth disk and there’s a full sized train with moving eyes just there. I don’t like it.

-Hela Shook

reblog.comment:
By FAR the most upsetting/unnerving thing in any marvel movie is in Ant Man when Scott hits a Thomas the tank engine toy with a growth disk and there’s a full sized train with moving eyes just there. I don’t like it.

-Hela Shook

summary: I can sadly confirm this isn’t an April Fools joke but an actual website with actual articles and reviews with the articles...
body:
I can sadly confirm this isn’t an April Fools joke but an actual website with actual articles and reviews with the articles written seemingly by one person.

It seems disturbingly fitting I post this on April Fools Day as this is the kind of shit you think would be an April Fools prank. But it isn’t. It really isn’t.

For the record the “Brie Larson Hates Her Castmates” article shoots itself in the foot by including the actual interview transcript and the context on the interview. Whoops.

title: Don´t mess with JARVIS
body:
You: *bored* JARVIS what´s the root of 368?
Jarvis: It is 19.1833260933
You: JARVIS sing Barry Manilows Copacabana
Jarvis: Her name was Lola, she was a showgirl
With yellow feathers in her hair and a dress cut down to there. She would merengue and do the cha-cha...
You: *5 minutes later still laughing* JARVIS start destruction mode! 
Jarvis: annihilation sequence starts in 10...9...8..
You: *starts to panic* STOP JARVIS!!
Jarvis: 7...6....5...
You: TONY!! I DIDN`T MEAN TO! TOOOONYYYY!!! 
Jarvis: 4...3...
You: *totaly in panic now* SHIT SHIT SHIT STOP!!! 
Jarvis: 2...1...
You:...
Jarvis:... Oh no! There seems to be a fault in the system!
You: JARVIS!!! 
Jarvis: *laughing* 
You: We are rubbing off on you...that´s not good! 

For the next 2 weeks you got woken up by the song Copacabana!

dialogue.name: Jarvis
dialogue.label: Jarvis:
dialogue.phrase: Her name was Lola, she was a showgirl
With yellow feathers in her hair and a dress cut down to there. She would merengue and do the cha-cha...

dialogue.name: You
dialogue.label: You:
dialogue.phrase: *5 minutes later still laughing* JARVIS start destruction mode!

dialogue.name: You
dialogue.label: You:
dialogue.phrase: TONY!! I DIDN`T MEAN TO! TOOOONYYYY!!!

dialogue.name: You
dialogue.label: You:
dialogue.phrase: *totaly in panic now* SHIT SHIT SHIT STOP!!!

dialogue.name: Jarvis
dialogue.label: Jarvis:
dialogue.phrase: ... Oh no! There seems to be a fault in the system!

dialogue.name: You
dialogue.label: You:
dialogue.phrase: We are rubbing off on you...that´s not good!
For the next 2 weeks you got woken up by the song Copacabana!

summary: Nesta segunda (1), a @netflixbrasil adicionou ao seu catálogo a primeira temporada da série da @freeform de @cloakanddaggertv...
caption:
Nesta segunda (1), a @netflixbrasil adicionou ao seu catálogo a primeira temporada da série da @freeform de @cloakanddaggertv (Manto & Adaga), dupla de heróis da @marvel/@marvelbrasil. Com base nisso, resgato um texto que fiz há dois anos para o Jovem Nerd (@nerdbunker), no qual falo um pouco da história da dupla das HQs e as espectativas do que poderia aparecer na serie. Confere no link da bio
.

title: I still remember you
description:
by Toastyshippers

John Watson is an omega that was mated to Sherlock Holmes, an alpha. The alpha died tragically from a car crash but his body was never found. The police never told John this, afraid that it’ll mess up the omega’s mind. They still perform a burial, just with an empty casket. John was really heartbroken when he knew about this.He visits Sherlock’s grave once in a while, telling him stories about…anything really

×I’m not the best at summaries but I hope you’ll give this fic a chance!×

ALSO this is a crossover between Sherlock and Marvel so :)) enjoy

Words: 709, Chapters: 1/1, Language: English

  • Fandoms: Sherlock (TV), Sherlock Holmes & Related Fandoms, Marvel Cinematic Universe, Doctor Strange (2016)
  • Rating: Not Rated
  • Warnings: Creator Chose Not To Use Archive Warnings, Major Character Death
  • Categories: M/M
  • Characters: Sherlock Holmes, John Watson, Stephen Strange, Tony Stark
  • Relationships: Tony Stark/Stephen Strange, Sherlock Holmes/John Watson, Sherlock Holmes/John Watson (past)
  • Additional Tags: Angst, like a l o t of angst, Alpha!Sherlock, Omega!John, omega!Tony, Alpha!Stephen, also sherlock dies, …maybe, You’ll see for yourself, also very ooc, and this happens before Thanos snaps his finger, Omegaverse, But its not really focused on that

blog.name: woolongtalks
blog.title: Woo Long Talks
blog.description: Black, British & Geeky! three friends who share our raw & honest opinions on the pop culture stuff we love. Join us!

summary: Episode 64 - Marvelous! 'Captain Marvel' review and discussion feat. Verbal Diorama!
title: Episode 64 - Marvelous! 'Captain Marvel' review and discussion feat. Verbal Diorama!
body:
Episode 64 – Marvelous! ‘Captain Marvel’ review and discussion feat. Verbal Diorama!

https://www.podbean.com/media/share/pb-sfyf7-aca46f

It’s time for us to dive into our review of Marvel Studios latest epic, ‘Captain Marvel’. We are joined by our special guest Em from ‘Verbal Diorama’ podcast to chat about the highs and lows of the movie, where it should rank among other MCU movies, it’s cultural impact and more!

You can subscribe to Em’s podcast, ‘Verbal Diorama’ here;
https://…

View On WordPress

blog.name: ashensunsets
blog.title: I Have No Idea What I'm Doing
blog.description: Pay no mind to the depressed, thirsty bitch behind the curtain. Black, nineteen years old, struggling biseuxal, she/her pronouns. Call me sunsets. My main fandom is the mcu, but I also love Supernatural, Pixar/Disney films, a shitton of cartoons, Shadowhunters, and occasionally Miraculous.

tags: but not entirely odin critical either
don't know what this is but i like it
title: Frigga Headcanon
body:
Frigga married into the royal line, right? There was no royal arrangements or anything to, say, make a prince and a princess come together with the hopes of one day ruling, right? Because if there is, we’re going to assume, for the sake of this post, and my inner fangirl, that it isn’t. Okay, here we go.

So Frigga was born a peasant.  Her parents, kind and tender-hearted, died in a plague that consumed the majority of her village, leaving their young child behind to navigate a decaying people. To survive, she begins to rely on her wits and her skills, the most prominent being her foresight. Her parents always disapproved of her foresight, speaking with venomous tongues of witchcraft and wicked natures, but Frigga’s a young girl just trying to earn enough coins for a loaf of bread. She can worry about the purity of her sou later. 

So she goes on that way. The years pass, the village continues to spiral into ruin, and Frigga gains something of a reputation as a fortune teller. The summer of her sixteenth year, a showman from Vanaheim strolls through and takes an interest in her, telling her that, along with foresight, she has the natural potential to be a mage. So Frigga takes to apprenticing under the showman’s hand, and, soon enough, tales begin to spread beyond the village of her skillset. 

Some years later, long after the showman’s moved on, Frigga’s grown to be a rather experienced mage, and she’s learned to use her foresight beyond silly parlor tricks. She’s at the local market one day, scowling at the usual scanty selection of foods, when a large hand lands upon her shoulder. Frigga turns around, instinctively reaching for the dagger in her pouch, when she places the face of the man standing before her. 

It’s the king. 

“Your majesty”, she says with an awkward courtesy before stepping aside. 

But the king just shakes his head and extends a hand to her. Reluctantly, Frigga accepts it. 

“I’m not here for trinkets or…” His eyes trail to the pitiful display of near rotten foods and emaciated cattle. “Local cuisines.” His eyes go bright and flicker back to her. “I’m here for you.”
Frigga raises an eyebrow and crosses her arms over her chest. “For me?”

“Yes. If you’ll pardon my gushing, I’ve heard a many tales of your work. You are, indeed, Frigga of the Forsaken, master of foresight and trickery, are you not?”
Frigga blinks, once twice. Then she smiles, lifting two fingers to her teeth, and bats her lashes. She’s aiming for shy, prude, mouse-like. And if the sight of air filling the fair king’s chest should mean anything, she’s succeeded. “’Tis I”, she replies in a low voice. “Do you have need of me?”

And just like that, Frigga finds her whole life changed. The next day, Odin sends for her, men doning golden chest plates and staffs arriving to escort her to the royal Palace. Odin says her stay is only for a few days, to entertain the celebration of some conquest or another, Frigga couldn’t really be bothered with to learn the details. She just sets up her tent and gets to work, taking the hands of the horrid men and women that come to her, smiling, telling them of all the success to come their way, and taking comfort in the demise that looms over their futures.

The celebration passes without event, and Frigga gets paid a year’s bounty in gratitude. Needless to say, when Odin sends a carriage for her a few months later, Frigga doesn’t need much persuasion. 

Things carry on in this manner for some time. Odin sending away for her a night or three, then sending her away by the time he must resume the regal facade of king. “It’s just not proper, you understand, for the king to associate with the likes of you”, he explained one evening, gloriously besotted off an obscure ale from Muspelheim. “I have a reputation to maintain afterall.”
Frigga, from where she sits draped across a sofa, just smirks. She twirls a finger along the rim of her own glass and takes a sip, delighted in the scorn present in the faces of the king’s many friends. 

Not long after, Odin makes a pass at her. Frigga accepts but only on the condition that she be granted full-time, free-range access to the Palace. And Odin, the bumbling, though sweet full that he is, does just that, ignoring the wishes and wisdom of his advisors and friends. It’s a shame. If Frigga were a malevolent woman, she could easily take advantage of the situation, use her newfound status to wreak havoc and chaos. But as it stands, Frigga was merely in pursuit of stability. And upon finding it, Frigga finds herself increasingly content with the course her life’s taken. 

She isn’t aloof. She’s followed the trickles of the river, and she knows that, should she decide to remain on the course, she’ll eventually be taken as his queen and come to bear him a child. She knows her life of living amongst the commonfolk, bedazzling them with her charms and knowledge of the future, are quickly fading and becoming something of a pastime. Frigga knows her life’s all but come to an end, all but become someone else’s. But she’s content with the fact. In no shape or form does she feel love for Odin, but she does consider him a good friend, regardless of his, at times, mad quest for blood. 

So Frigga bears the good king a son. And when the time comes that the madman come home from battle with another child, this one with skin as blue the eyes of her firstborn, Frigga takes it in stride, requesting, only that he cease in his “extracurricular activities”. “We have no need of a tyrant, my sweet”, Frigga murmurs one night in bed, a son on each leg as she watches her husband frantically pacing the room. She reaches out and takes hold of his hand, smiles. “Be a king. Be a father.”

To no one’s surprise, he puts more effort into one than the other, but Frigga isn’t much too bothered. She has the lives of two unruly sons to attend to, one which, oddly enough, has a future to which she cannot perceive. 
In a way, she’s not surprised. She’s never met a Jotun before, and she’s certainly never heard of them having the touch of the magics. Her other son is much the same. He is the son of Odin, and he most certainly lives up to the name. But whereas her husband is blunt and at times cruel, Thor is kind and compassionate, if a bit hotheaded at times. He and Loki come to quarrell quite often, and it makes Frigga worry, for them, for the kingdom, for the future, which, as the days pass, is becoming more and more murky. Her foresight’s failing her, something Odin passes off as her “losing her touch”.

But Frigga can see the future just find. It’s her son she can’t see. 

For a time, she considers consulting her friends. Friends which she hasn’t seen or heard from in years but friends nonetheless. And on quite a few occasions, she does go to meet them. But whenever she does, she always thinks of something that showman once said: that the power of foresight if a strong, powerful force; that using it to predict the future is one thing and that using it to control the future is another. 

So Frigga keeps her worries to herself. Her meetings with her friends remain cordial and quaint, and her reputation as a mage and seer flounder, even as the future grows more and more uncertain.

In no shape or form does she feel love for Odin, but she does consider him a good friend, regardless of his, at times, mad quest for blood. 

So Frigga bears the good king a son. And when the time comes that the madman come home from battle with another child, this one with skin as blue the eyes of her firstborn, Frigga takes it in stride, requesting, only that he cease in his “extracurricular activities”. “We have no need of a tyrant, my sweet”, Frigga murmurs one night in bed, a son on each leg as she watches her husband frantically pacing the room. She reaches out and takes hold of his hand, smiles. “Be a king. Be a father.”

To no one’s surprise, he puts more effort into one than the other, but Frigga isn’t much too bothered. She has the lives of two unruly sons to attend to, one which, oddly enough, has a future to which she cannot perceive. 
In a way, she’s not surprised. She’s never met a Jotun before, and she’s certainly never heard of them having the touch of the magics. Her other son is much the same. He is the son of Odin, and he most certainly lives up to the name. But whereas her husband is blunt and at times cruel, Thor is kind and compassionate, if a bit hotheaded at times. He and Loki come to quarrell quite often, and it makes Frigga worry, for them, for the kingdom, for the future, which, as the days pass, is becoming more and more murky. Her foresight’s failing her, something Odin passes off as her “losing her touch”.

But Frigga can see the future just find. It’s her son she can’t see. 

For a time, she considers consulting her friends. Friends which she hasn’t seen or heard from in years but friends nonetheless. And on quite a few occasions, she does go to meet them. But whenever she does, she always thinks of something that showman once said: that the power of foresight if a strong, powerful force; that using it to predict the future is one thing and that using it to control the future is another. 

So Frigga keeps her worries to herself. Her meetings with her friends remain cordial and quaint, and her reputation as a mage and seer flounder, even as the future grows more and more uncertain.
